sites.name: Diocletian's Palace
sites.description: Split's most iconic landmark, this massive palace complex was built by Roman Emperor Diocletian in the 4th century AD. The palace covers 30,000 square meters and includes the emperor's residence, military barracks, and religious buildings. Today, it's a living monument where people still live and work within its ancient walls. The palace features the Peristyle (central square), the Cathedral of Saint Domnius (originally Diocletian's mausoleum), and numerous Roman architectural elements. This UNESCO World Heritage site is the heart of Split's Old Town and offers visitors a unique blend of ancient history and modern life.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer months are extremely busy with cruise ship visitors. Spring and fall offer pleasant weather and fewer crowds. Winter provides a peaceful experience with mild temperatures. Early morning visits avoid both crowds and the intense midday sun.
sites.booking_tips: No entrance fee required for the palace grounds. Guided tours are available and recommended to understand the complex history. The palace is pedestrian-only and perfect for leisurely exploration. Best to visit early morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds and heat.

sites.name: Riva (Waterfront Promenade)
sites.description: Split's vibrant waterfront promenade stretches along the Adriatic Sea and serves as the city's social and cultural center. This pedestrian-only area is lined with palm trees, cafes, restaurants, and historic buildings. The Riva is where locals gather for coffee, evening strolls, and socializing. The promenade offers spectacular views of the harbor, nearby islands, and the Marjan hill. It's particularly magical in the evening when the lights reflect on the water and the atmosphere becomes lively with street performers and outdoor dining.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer brings large crowds and cruise ship visitors. Spring and fall offer a more authentic experience. Winter provides a peaceful atmosphere with fewer tourists. The promenade is most atmospheric in the early morning or evening when cruise ship crowds have dispersed.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Visit early morning or evening to avoid cruise ship crowds. The promenade is pedestrian-only and perfect for leisurely strolls. Many cafes and restaurants line the waterfront, making it ideal for dining and people-watching.

sites.name: Cathedral of Saint Domnius
sites.description: Originally built as Diocletian's mausoleum in the 4th century, this cathedral was converted to a Christian church in the 7th century. The cathedral combines Roman, Byzantine, and medieval architectural elements, featuring a distinctive octagonal structure and a beautiful bell tower. The interior houses religious art, including works by local and Italian artists. The cathedral's architecture reflects Split's complex history from Roman times through the Middle Ages.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round for worship and visitors. Summer brings many tourists. Winter offers a more peaceful experience. The cathedral is particularly atmospheric during religious services. The bell tower has separate opening hours and admission fee.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to avoid queues during peak season. Dress respectfully as this is an active place of worship. The bell tower requires a separate ticket. Photography is permitted but flash is not allowed. Allow 30-45 minutes for a visit.

sites.name: Peristyle
sites.description: The central square of Diocletian's Palace, this magnificent space was the heart of the Roman palace complex. Surrounded by Corinthian columns and featuring the Cathedral of Saint Domnius, the Peristyle is one of the most impressive Roman architectural ensembles in the world. The square is still used for cultural events, concerts, and performances, maintaining its role as a gathering place for over 1,700 years.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer brings many tourists and cultural events. Spring and fall offer pleasant weather and fewer crowds. Winter provides a peaceful experience. The square is particularly atmospheric during evening cultural events.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Visit early morning or evening to avoid crowds. The square is pedestrian-only and perfect for photography. Cultural events are often held here in summer months.

sites.name: Marjan Hill
sites.description: This forested hill rises 178 meters above Split and offers the most spectacular panoramic views of the city, Old Town, and surrounding islands. Visitors can reach the summit by hiking, cycling, or driving. The hill features walking paths, viewpoints, a small zoo, and the historic Church of Saint Nicholas. The views are particularly stunning at sunrise and sunset, making it a favorite spot for photographers and nature lovers.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round but may be slippery in wet weather. Summer offers the longest daylight hours. Winter provides clear views but shorter daylight hours. Sunset visits offer the most dramatic lighting for photography.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. The hike to the top takes about 30 minutes and is moderately challenging. Wear comfortable walking shoes. The hill is perfect for a morning jog or evening stroll.

sites.name: Bacvice Beach
sites.description: Split's most popular beach, located just a short walk from the Old Town, offers crystal-clear waters and a vibrant atmosphere. The beach features fine sand, shallow waters perfect for swimming, and numerous beach bars and restaurants. Bacvice is famous for being the birthplace of picigin, a traditional Croatian ball game played in shallow water. The beach is particularly beautiful at sunset when the Old Town is illuminated.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer is the most popular time with warm water temperatures. Spring and fall offer pleasant swimming conditions with fewer crowds. Winter is too cold for swimming but offers peaceful walks along the beach.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Bring your own towels and beach gear. Beach bars and restaurants are available but can be expensive. The beach can get crowded during peak season. Arrive early to secure a good spot.

sites.name: Split Archaeological Museum
sites.description: The oldest museum in Croatia, founded in 1820, houses an extensive collection of artifacts from Split's Roman and medieval periods. The museum features Roman sculptures, mosaics, coins, and everyday objects from Diocletian's era. The collection provides insight into Split's rich history and the daily life of its Roman inhabitants.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled galleries. Summer brings higher visitor numbers, especially families. Winter offers a quieter experience. The museum is a good option for rainy days.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to avoid queues during peak season. Allow 1-1.5 hours for a visit. The museum is relatively small but informative. Audio guides available in multiple languages.

sites.name: Game of Thrones Walking Tour
sites.description: Split served as a filming location for Daenerys Targaryen's throne room and other scenes in HBO's Game of Thrones. This guided tour takes visitors to the actual filming locations around Diocletian's Palace, including the cellars, Peristyle, and various streets. Guides provide behind-the-scenes information and show photos from the filming process. The tour combines entertainment with historical information about Split.
sites.seasonal_notes: Available year-round but most popular during peak tourist season. Summer tours can be crowded. Spring and fall offer pleasant weather for walking. Winter provides a more intimate experience with smaller groups.
sites.booking_tips: Book online in advance, especially during peak season. Tours typically last 2-3 hours. Wear comfortable walking shoes. Tours are available in multiple languages. Some tours include entrance fees to attractions.

sites.name: Split Summer Festival
sites.description: This prestigious cultural festival, held annually from mid-July to mid-August, features classical music, theater, opera, and dance performances in historic venues throughout the Old Town. Performances take place in open-air locations like the Peristyle, Diocletian's cellars, and various squares. The festival has been running since 1954 and attracts world-class artists and performers.
sites.seasonal_notes: Held annually from mid-July to mid-August. Tickets sell out quickly for popular performances. The festival coincides with peak tourist season. Some performances are free, others require tickets.
sites.booking_tips: Book tickets well in advance, especially for popular performances. Some events are free and held in public squares. Check the festival schedule online. Dress appropriately for evening performances.

sites.name: Diocletian's Cellars
sites.description: These extensive underground chambers beneath Diocletian's Palace were originally used for storage and as a foundation for the palace above. Today, they house shops, galleries, and cultural spaces. The cellars provide insight into Roman engineering and are a popular venue for cultural events and exhibitions. The underground complex is one of the best-preserved examples of Roman architecture in the world.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with constant cool temperature. Summer offers relief from the heat. Winter provides a warm refuge. The cellars are particularly atmospheric during cultural events.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Guided tours are available for deeper historical context. The cellars can be cool, so bring a light jacket. Allow 1 hour for exploration.

sites.name: Fruit Square (Trg Brace Radic)
sites.description: This charming square in the heart of Split's Old Town is surrounded by historic buildings and features a statue of Marko Marulić, Croatia's greatest Renaissance poet. The square is lined with cafes, restaurants, and shops, making it a perfect spot for people-watching and enjoying local cuisine. The square's name comes from the fruit market that was once held here.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer brings many tourists and outdoor dining. Spring and fall offer pleasant weather and fewer crowds. Winter provides a cozy atmosphere with indoor cafes. The square is most lively in the evening.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Visit early morning or evening to avoid crowds. The square is pedestrian-only and perfect for leisurely strolls. Many cafes and restaurants offer outdoor seating.

sites.name: Mestrovic Gallery
sites.description: Housed in a villa designed by Croatia's most famous sculptor, Ivan Meštrović, this museum showcases his works in a beautiful setting overlooking the sea. The gallery features sculptures, drawings, and architectural models, providing insight into the artist's creative process and Croatian cultural heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled galleries. Summer brings higher visitor numbers. Winter offers a quieter experience. The villa's architecture and sea views are highlights.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to avoid queues during peak season. Allow 1-1.5 hours for a visit. The gallery is located outside the Old Town but easily accessible by bus or taxi.

sites.name: Klis Fortress
sites.description: This medieval fortress, located about 10 kilometers from Split, offers spectacular views of the city and surrounding countryside. The fortress played a crucial role in defending the region from Ottoman invasions and was featured in Game of Thrones as the city of Meereen. Today, it houses a museum and provides visitors with insight into Croatia's medieval history.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer brings many visitors and can be hot. Spring and fall offer pleasant weather and fewer crowds. Winter provides a peaceful experience with dramatic views. The fortress is particularly atmospheric during sunset.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to avoid queues. The fortress is accessible by car or bus from Split. Allow 2 hours for a comprehensive visit. Wear comfortable walking shoes for the steep climb.

sites.name: Trogir
sites.description: This charming medieval town, located about 30 kilometers from Split, is a UNESCO World Heritage site. Trogir features well-preserved Romanesque and Renaissance architecture, including the Cathedral of Saint Lawrence and the Kamerlengo Fortress. The town's narrow streets, historic buildings, and waterfront promenade make it a perfect day trip from Split.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer brings tourists but is less crowded than Split. Spring and fall offer pleasant weather and a more authentic experience. Winter is quiet and peaceful. The town is accessible year-round by bus or boat from Split.
sites.booking_tips: Reach Trogir by bus from Split or by boat from the harbor. No booking required for general visits. Allow 3-4 hours for a comprehensive visit. The town is perfect for a day trip from Split.
